At that time, Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Great Wisdom... Because of the above entry into
the three gates of liberation, he quickly attained enlightenment. Therefore, Great Wisdom requested the TathÄgata to speak, as all
bodhisattvas and others practiced the method of effortless skillful means.
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas... are then called great practitioners.
The TathÄgata said that possessing the four skillful means can accomplish great practice. This brings up the four names, which will be explained below.
Great Wisdom!
What is observing one's own mind's manifestations... thus observing one's own mind's manifestations.

This means that the dharmas of the three realms, such as the dependent and the directly perceived, are only the manifestations of one's own mind's past habits and perfuming, and the objects of discrimination and entry.
As the Awakening of Faith says: All dharmas arise from the mind's false thoughts.
Observing in this way is called right observation.
Great Wisdom!
How can one be free from the views of arising, abiding, and ceasing?
Up to the point of transforming the basis of consciousness and attaining the body of mind-made manifestation.

As for being free from the view of arising, it means that at the completion of the seventh ground, the stage of effort is finished, and within the two kinds of arising, one is able to be free from the view of the characteristics of arising.
Realizing the illusory nature, abiding in the eighth ground, understanding mind, consciousness, and so forth.
As for the body of mind-made manifestation, it is the effortless path, the body of mind-made manifestation that realizes the intrinsic nature of dharmas.
Mahamati said:
World-Honored One!
For what causes and conditions is it called the body of mind-made manifestation?
Because the above eighth ground bodhisattvas are said to transform the basis of consciousness, how can it also be called the body of mind-made manifestation?
Therefore, it is asked, For what causes and conditions is the body of mind-made manifestation?
The Buddha said:
Mahamati!
The body of mind-made manifestation is attained by being free from the views of arising, abiding, and ceasing.
The mind has three meanings, so the mind is taken as a metaphor:

First, swiftness; second, unobstructedness; third, universal attainment. It is used as a metaphor for bodhisattvas attaining the illusory samÄdhi, manifesting forms in the ten directions to transform sentient beings, and also having these three meanings.
From The body born of the mind is also like this onward, it combines the Dharma with the metaphor, which can be understood.
Great Wisdom!
How does one observe the naturelessness of external phenomena?
You should diligently cultivate and study in this way.
This clarifies the cultivation of the four kinds of true practices, which accomplish the above four kinds of Dharma gates.
Namely, observing the activities manifested by one's own mind accomplishes the above Dharma gate of the emptiness of all phenomena.
Far away from the views and practices of arising, abiding, and ceasing, one accomplishes the above Dharma gate of non-arising.
Skillfully knowing the naturelessness of external phenomena, one accomplishes the above Dharma gate of selflessness.
Single-mindedly seeking one's own realization of the holy wisdom, one accomplishes the above Dharma gate of non-duality.
These are called the four dharmas that bodhisattvas accomplish, attaining the great skillful means of practice as it is. Therefore, I exhort you to diligently practice and study.
At that time, Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Great Wisdom... up to... not falsely grasping at the gradual or sudden arising of dharmas.
Because of seeing above that the arising of the three realms is due to deluded thoughts, Great Wisdom raises the characteristics of causes and conditions to inquire.
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
All dharmas arise from causes and conditions... up to... this is called the external conditions arising in sequence before and after.
It is said that the lump of clay is the cause, and water, stick, etc. are the conditions, forming the result of the pot.
Just as the cause and effect of the clay pot are like this, the other four such as thread and cloth, etc. are also the same.
All using thread, grass, seeds, and curd as their causes, cloth, mats, sprouts, and butter as their effects, the meaning of conditions can be understood.
This is called the dharma of dependent arising, which must first have causes and then effects arising in sequence.
It means that the direct producer is the cause, and the indirect helper is the condition.
The internal means ignorance, craving, karma, and so forth, up to this is only the discrimination of the foolish.
The internal conditions refer to using ignorance, craving, karma, and so forth as causal conditions to give rise to the aggregates, realms, and sense bases of the body, which are called the effects.
This is only the false discrimination of the foolish, each seeing differences.
It is extensively explained in the Chapter on Refuting Causal Conditions in the Madhyamaka-Å›Ästra.
However, the external is transformed by the internal, with the primary and secondary mutually encompassing each other, forming a single dependent origination.
Great Wisdom!
There are six kinds of causes:
Namely, the cause of what is to come, up to the cause of observation.
Above, it generally discusses all internal and external causes and conditions.
From here on, it specifically discusses the six kinds of causes and four kinds of conditions, which are all the self-discriminations of the foolish.
Great Wisdom!
The cause of what is to come means the internal and external dharmas acting as causes to give rise to effects.
The later effect that arises is called future existence, which is the present creation of causes and the future attainment of effects, called the cause of future existence.
The associated cause refers to internal and external dharmas that take objects and produce aggregates such as seeds.
It means that after taking objects, internal and external dharmas arise, and the able and the acted upon, cause and effect, are mutually associated.
Aggregates are the effect.
Seeds are the cause.ğŸ”½The similar cause refers to that which takes the uninterrupted similar as its object and produces a continuous effect.
It means that the mutual effect of each other is called the similar cause.
The Abhidharma Treatise says: Co-existent dharmas are mutually effects, like the characteristics and the characterized, the mind and the mental factors that accompany it.
It means that the characteristics of conditioned dharmas are with respect to conditioned dharmas, and conditioned dharmas are with respect to the characteristics of conditioned dharmas;

the mind is with respect to the mental factors that accompany the mind, and the mental factors that accompany the mind are with respect to the mind. Because they are mutually effects, they are also called the co-existent cause.
The efficient cause means that which produces a dominant effect, like a wheel-turning king.
All conditioned things, except for themselves, take all dharmas as their efficient causes, because when they arise, there is no obstruction.
It is like the people of a country, who, because the wheel-turning king does not harm them, all say:
We obtain peace and happiness because of the wheel-turning king.
The revealing cause means that which, arising from discrimination, can reveal the characteristics of objects, like a lamp illuminating things.
It is said that when the events of deluded thoughts arise, they can reveal the characteristics of objects.
The subject and object, cause and effect, mutually illuminate each other, like a lamp illuminating things.
The conditional cause means that when cessation is related to the discontinuity of deluded thoughts, they do not arise.
It is like long and short, high and low, mutually conditioning each other. Cause and effect are also like this.
Because the cause ceases and the effect arises, it is called cessation is related to discontinuity. One does not see deluded thoughts arising.
Great Wisdom!
This is the self-discrimination of foolish people. When seeking its causal characteristics, they cannot be obtained.
Below this, it refutes the six kinds of causes and conditions that are the characteristics of the mind's deluded thoughts.
If it is said to be born suddenly, then the active and passive, cause and effect, are no different. How can there be the characteristics of a cause?
If it is said to be born gradually, when seeking its essence and characteristics, they also cannot be obtained. How can one who has not yet given birth to a child be called a father?
It is said that one who has not yet given birth to a child cannot be called a father. This one analogy refutes both views.
If cause and effect are born suddenly at the same time, then it is like father and son having the same essence, and their superior and inferior status cannot be distinguished.
If the cause precedes and the effect follows, then the father precedes and the son follows. If the son is definitely later, how can the father be called from?
Accusing it with this, both views are completely lost. The father is likened to the cause, and the son is likened to the effect.
It is also said that because there is no father, one cannot be called a son. Because the previous part has already ceased, the later part cannot be named in sequence.
The people who make conceptual distinctions say that due to causes and conditions, up to all are the characteristics of attachment to false conceptualization.
This explains that the one who falsely conceptualizes the four conditions, that which is able to directly produce results is called the causal condition;
Because they rely on each other, it is called the condition of the object;
The preceding and succeeding opening and guiding are called the sequential;
The meaning of not obstructing arising is called the dominant.
The people who make conceptual distinctions, by means of these four conditions, the dharmas that are produced and that which produces them, the sequence of mutual dependence, are all unobtainable.
They are only the characteristics of the mind's conceptualization and attachment.
The extensive meaning of the four conditions is as explained in the VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ-Å›Ästra.
Great Wisdom!
Gradual and sudden are all not produced, up to the views of gradual and sudden production.

The Buddha formerly used skillful means to explain that all dharmas are produced from causes and conditions, in order to refute the non-Buddhist teachings of spontaneous origination, no causes, and wrong causes.
He also explained that conditioned arising is without self, in order to refute the non-Buddhist teachings that grasp at the existence of a self.
As a verse says: In order to refute the creator, the combination of causes and conditions is spoken of.
In order to refute the fault of permanence, conditions are said to be impermanent.

Now, in this assembly, in order to abandon the provisional vehicle and reach the realization of mind-only, it is concluded by refuting and saying that one should depart from the views of sudden and gradual arising within the characteristics of the combination of causes and conditions.
However, in refuting different views, there are generally three explanations in the provisional and true teachings:
First, it is to cause the bodhisattvas to know that all dharmas arise from causes and conditions, unlike the views of non-Buddhists;
Second, to know that they arise from the mind, abandoning the views of the two vehicles;
Third, the arising of the nature of mind-only is not the same as in the provisional teachings.
Learners should know this.

At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½All dharmas are without arising and also without ceasing. Within those conditions, the characteristics of arising and ceasing are discriminated.
Because all dharmas are without arising, cessation cannot be spoken of. It is just that within those unreal conditions, the characteristics of arising and ceasing are falsely discriminated.
It does not deny that conditions come together, and thus cessation arises again, but only stops the deluded feelings of ordinary fools.

It clarifies that the Buddha does not deny that dependent origination ceases and arises again, because the intrinsic nature of dharmas is unborn, and it is only to eliminate the attachments conceptualized by the deluded thoughts of ordinary fools.
Dharmas in conditions, whether existent or non-existent, are all without arising. The mind is deluded and turns due to habitual tendencies, and from this the three realms of existence appear.

It says that whether dependent origination is existent or non-existent, all dharmas are without arising, and only the three realms of existence appear due to the deluded turning of one's own mind from habitual tendencies.
The three realms of existence refer to the realm of desire, the realm of form, and the formless realm.
Originally there is no arising, and also no cessation... yet it is said there is arising and cessation.

If one is free from the two graspings and all false views, then one will know that the dharmas that arise and the causes and conditions that give rise to them are all originally non-existent, and it is not that one analyzes them to make them non-existent.
At that time, Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Great Wisdom... up to ... will attain purity in the two meanings.
Because of the above statement:
But only in accordance with worldly convention, therefore it is said there is arising and ceasing.
Therefore, Great Wisdom raised the characteristics of verbal distinctions and the Dharma door of the mind to inquire.
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
There are four kinds of characteristics of verbal distinctions... these are the four.
The four kinds of verbal distinctions can be understood from the text.

Moreover, as for verbal distinctions in dreams, it is also said that when the bodhisattvas of the eighth ground attain the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas and awaken, they realize that the previously experienced realms from the stage of resolve and practice up to the seventh ground are unreal, and they speak of all dharmas as being like dreams, thus it is called verbal distinctions in dreams.
Great Wisdom further said:
World-Honored One... up to ... where do they arise from? what causes do they have? how do they arise?
He asked about the place from which verbal distinctions emerge.
He asked about the causes from which verbal distinctions are born.
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
It arises in dependence on the head, chest, throat, lips, palate, teeth, and tongue in combination.
These various conditions are the source of verbal expression.
Mahamati said again:
World-Honored One!
Language is conceptualization. Conceptualization arises as the cause of language.
This means that verbal expression arises from conceptualization.
If they were different, conceptualization should not be the cause. Up to this point, therefore, they are neither different nor not different.
If verbal expression were different from conceptualization, it should not arise from conceptualization.

If verbal expression were not different from conceptualization, since conceptualization does not manifest meaning, verbal expression should also not manifest meaning. Yet verbal expression can manifest meaning. Therefore, neither is the case.
Mahamati said again:ğŸ”½World-Honored One!
Up to this point, one enters the ultimate truth by relying on words, but it is not the same as words.
Because of the above statement that verbal expression can manifest meaning, Mahamati asks whether verbal expression is the ultimate truth,
or whether what is expressed is the ultimate truth?
And he raised the supreme principle of the Dharma of the first mind to ask about it.
The Buddha replied:
It is not language, nor is it what is spoken.
Why is it so?
The supreme principle is the realm of the bliss of the samÄdhi of the holy wisdom of self-realization. It is entered through words, but it is not the words themselves.
Therefore, killing is like pointing at the moon. If one sees the moon, one knows that the pointing is ultimately not the moon.
The supreme principle is the realm of the holy wisdom of self-realization within oneself, up to the supreme principle, one is unable to reveal it.
Language arises and ceases, moving and shaking, and is therefore impermanent. Arising from various conditions, it has no self-nature. How can it reveal the supreme principle?
The supreme principle has no self or other characteristics, up to one should distance oneself from verbal discrimination.
It is said that the supreme truth transcends self and other characteristics, because verbal expression involves the characteristics of existence, it cannot reveal it.

Moreover, the ultimate truth is only the realization of the intrinsic nature of the true mind. There are no dharmas outside the mind. All external various dharmas are all without intrinsic nature. How can words and thoughts be able to reveal it?
Therefore, it is advised to leave behind verbal distinctions and rely on the ultimate truth.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
All dharmas are without self-nature, and also without words. Not seeing the meaning of emptiness and emptiness, foolish people thus flow and transmigrate.

Because all dharmas are without substance, they are also without words. Foolish people do not see the emptiness of words and the emptiness of what is spoken, thus they flow and transmigrate through birth and death.
All dharmas are without intrinsic nature, apart from verbal distinctions. All existences are like dreams and illusions, neither birth and death nor nirvana.
It is said that all dharmas and words are unreal, like dreams and illusions.
How can those who are like dreams and illusions have the definite characteristics of birth and death or nirvana?
Like a king and an elder, in order to delight their children, up to personally realizing the Dharma of ultimate reality.
The first verse gives the analogy, the following verse applies the analogy to the Dharma.
It means that what I am now expounding is the realm of the ultimate reality of self-realized holy wisdom, not what is spoken by verbal expression.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Great Wisdom... the realm of the practice of self-realized holy wisdom.

Great Wisdom, based on the above statement that the ultimate truth is attained by self-realized holy wisdom, not the realm of verbal discrimination, then raises the ultimate truth attained by self-realized holy wisdom to ask about it.

However, the essence of the ultimate truth is free from the four propositions of identity, difference, existence, nonexistence, annihilation, permanence, and both existence and nonexistence, therefore Great Wisdom asks about the Dharma free from the four propositions.
Herein, three dharmas are explained to clarify the twelve propositions, with nine propositions in the text, appearing and disappearing alternately.
Identity and difference have four propositions, existence and nonexistence have three propositions, permanence and impermanence have two propositions, omitted by the text.
Fully as explained in the Treatise on the Four Doctrines.
Far removed from the false imagination of self-characteristics, up to being endowed with and perfectly complete in all merits.

It is said that not only is it free from the views of non-Buddhists, it is also free from the views of the two vehicles grasping at the self-characteristics and common characteristics of the aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields, enabling all bodhisattvas and sentient beings to quickly realize the TathÄgata's unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
Up to permanence, impermanence, and so forth, all self-natures.
Although it was said above to be free from existence and non-existence, etc., it is not yet known what is existence and non-existence?
Now it correctly brings forth the essence of existence and non-existence.

It is said that ordinary beings, out of foolishness, do not know that it is the transformations produced by the causes of their own mind's deluded habits, and they cling to external phenomena as existent or non-existent, giving rise to the views of the four propositions, etc. This is the essence of falsely imagined existence and non-existence.
The following twelve analogies illustrate that these dharmas of existence and non-existence, identity and difference, etc. are all not real, and should be far removed from.
Answer: Above, it was asked to explain for me the realm of activity that is free from identity, difference, existence, non-existence, permanence, impermanence, and so forth.
SubhÅ«ti!
It is like a herd of animals tormented by thirst, who see a mirage as water and run towards it, falling into the trap of attachment to identity and difference.
Deer chasing a mirage, how much more so do fools delight in sense objects. It says foolish ordinary beings are also like this, which corresponds to the herd of animals above.
Tormented by the three poisons of afflictions accumulated from beginningless time, it corresponds to being tormented by thirst.
Delighting in sense objects, seeing arising and ceasing, it corresponds to seeing a mirage as water in the heat.
Grasping inner and outer dharmas, falling into the trap of attachment to identity and difference, it corresponds to being confused, running towards it, not knowing it is not water.
SubhÅ«ti!
Like a gandharva city, one should know that the three kinds of inference are also like this, arising from the discrimination of existence, apart from the two natures of self and dharmas.
As for the three kinds of valid cognition:
The first is direct valid cognition, the second is inferential valid cognition, and the third is scriptural valid cognition.
Measurement refers to a standard definition, like measuring objects with a bushel or a peck.

Direct perception means directly manifesting, referring to clearly verifying an object, not involving names or phrases, without a mind of speculation, personally attaining the essence of dharmas, free from false discrimination, and not being mistaken.
Inference means inferring by means of causes, reasons, and analogies, and thus knowing by inferential measurement.
For example, seeing smoke in the distance one must know there is fire, seeing horns through a wall one must know it is an ox. Although not directly seen, it is not false.
The words of the Sage means taking the teachings of the TathÄgata as the standard.
Therefore, the ancient sages said:
After the Buddha's extinction, using sÅ«tras and Å›Ästras as the standard, and taking knowledge as the guide, to prevent the intrusion of demons and outsiders.
The five-part debate method:
1. Thesis, 2. Reason, 3. Example, 4. Application, 5. Conclusion.
The three - thesis, reason, and example - are also called the three parts of inference, with the example only serving to complete it.
For example, non-Buddhists falsely imagine and cling to sound as being permanent.
In the science of sound, they establish a logical argument, saying:
Sound is the subject, and its definitiveness as permanent is the thesis.
The reason is because it has the nature of being produced, with an example like space.
However, if space does not have the nature of being produced, then the reason will not apply, and the example will not be equal, so establishing sound as permanent will not be accomplished.
If in the Buddhist teachings sound is impermanent, then a logical argument is established, saying:
Sound is the subject, and its definitiveness as impermanent is the thesis.
The reason is because it has the nature of being produced, with an example like a vase.
As the Shurangama Sutra says, Sounds mixed with language only rely on names, phrases, and flavors.
How could it be permanent?

The various imaginations and attachments of non-Buddhists consider themselves to surpass others. If one does not use their own logical arguments to infer and refute them, how can one refute their attachments?
Therefore, the five-part treatise spoken by the TathÄgata is like using a wedge to remove a wedge, or using sound to stop sound.

It is called the destruction of the heterodox views of demons and outsiders, the determination of the fundamental principles of the Buddha's teachings, and the liberation of all sentient beings from various heterodox views such as existence and non-existence in the realm realized by the holy wisdom of self-realization.
Foolish people who are confused by the teachings still conceive of existence, oneness, difference, annihilation, and permanence through conceptual discrimination.
SubhÅ«ti!
All practitioners who transform the mind, thought, and consciousness will then become attached to self, person, sentient being, and life.

All practitioners should extinguish the mind, thought, and consciousness, depart from the two kinds of self-nature of the grasper and the grasped, enter the stage of the TathÄgata, and not give rise to conceptualization regarding existence and non-existence.
If one makes judgments of existence and non-existence regarding the realm realized by self-realization, one will still become attached to self and what belongs to self.
SubhÅ«ti!
All dharmas have their own characteristics and common characteristics... the realm of the bliss of samÄdhi realized by the holy wisdom of self-realization.

The term transformation Buddha is used to conform to the deluded views that arise in foolish people. Various teachings are given, speaking of specific and general characteristics, in order to make them understand that phenomena are not real.
Not a non-Buddha is translated in both the Song and Wei editions as dharma Buddha.
Great Wisdom!
It is like a tree reflected in the water. All discriminations, such as being and non-being, one and different, arising and ceasing, eternal and impermanent, are the same.
The TathÄgata concludes by exhorting.

Within the realization, one should abandon the above evil views and discriminations of ordinary beings, non-Buddhists, arising and ceasing, one and different, being and non-being, eternalism and nihilism, and being and non-being.
However, the heretical views of India are roughly of three types:
First, non-Buddhist paths outside of Buddhism.
Such as the above four propositions and the sixty-two non-Buddhist paths of the six teachers.
Second, non-Buddhist paths attached to Buddhism.
Arising from the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«ya and PrajÃ±aptivÄda, they consider themselves intelligent and read Buddhist scriptures, but due to lack of right views, they give rise to false understandings.
It is like a cow drinking water becoming milk, and a snake drinking water becoming poison. All the masters reject this, as these people are those with wrong views attached to Buddhism.
Third, studying Buddhism and becoming a non-Buddhist.
Grasping the Buddhist teachings, but giving rise to vexation and not attaining realization.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says, If one does not attain the skillful means of prajÃ±Ä, entering the Abhidharma one falls into existence;
entering emptiness one falls into non-existence;
entering the KunÄla sÅ«tra one falls into both existence and non-existence.
The Madhyamaka-Å›Ästra says, Grasping neither existence nor non-existence is called foolish discourse. Mistakenly grasping the true Dharma, one still becomes a person with wrong views.
Moreover, all four gates of the MahÄyÄna become views. The truth is false, because it gives rise to views of birth;
nirvÄá¹‡a is saá¹ƒsÄra, because it gives rise to craving and attachment.
Taking too much sweet dew injures one's life and causes an early death. Losing the skillful means gate, one falls into wrong grasping, thus it is called inner wrong views.
Therefore, know that dharmas have no fixed characteristics, they revolve according to the mind. If grasped, they become wrong; if penetrated, there is no fault.
It is like the dharma of the four propositions, their permissibility and obstruction depend on the person.

In the dharma, they are called the four propositions; when realized, they are called the four gates; when falsely conceived, they are called the four attachments; when disparaged, they are called the four denials.
The four propositions are unmoving, gain and loss arise from emptiness;
one dharma is without error, rising and sinking differ by themselves.

But if there is something to be valued and relied upon, establishing knowledge and understanding, even a slight trace of seeing not forgotten, all become non-Buddhist paths. Therefore, know that with views one is an ordinary person, with the emotions gone one is a Buddha.
At that time the World Honored One again spoke a verse, saying:
The five aggregates of consciousness are like a water-tree reflection, what is seen is like a dream illusion, one should not falsely discriminate.
This verse compares the three metaphors above to the five aggregates, one should not falsely give rise to discrimination.
The three existences are like a mirage, an illusion, a dream, and a hair wheel, if one can view them thus, one will ultimately attain liberation.
The verse summarizes the four analogies to clarify that the three non-existents are unreal, and that by contemplating this one will surely attain bodhi.
Just like a mirage in hot weather, moving and confusing the mind, fools give rise to attachment.
The first verse summarizes the first analogy, and the next verse summarizes the doctrinal correspondence.
In beginningless birth and death, one is entangled and obscured by attachment.
The verse generally summarizes the meaning of the twelve analogies, because in beginningless [time] one is entangled and obscured by attachment to the self and dharmas.
One should abandon and escape them, like using a wedge to remove a wedge.
The above twelve analogies are like using a reverse wedge to remove the wedge of birth and death.
Illusions, spells, and mechanical creations, floating clouds, dreams, and lightning, contemplate the world as always being like this, forever severing the three continuities.
The verse also summarizes the five analogies, contemplating the world as always being like this, able to sever the three realms and forever have no continuity.
Floating clouds and lightning are not mentioned above.
Herein there is nothing, like a mirage in the sky. Thus knowing all dharmas is to know nothing.
It is said that knowing the non-substantiality of all dharmas is to have nothing to know.
The skandhas are like a spinning firebrand, falsely discriminated therein. Only provisional names are established, but their characteristics cannot be obtained.
It is said that the aggregates do not exist, and even the provisional names are empty, without self-nature characteristics.
Like a painting, hanging hair, an illusion, a dream, a gandharva city, up to the foolish falsely discriminating.
It also comprehensively illustrates the seven analogies, showing that the four propositions of existence and non-existence, identity and difference, permanence and impermanence, etc. are not real.
The painting analogy is not in the above text.
A clear mirror, still water, a pure eye, a wonderful jewel, up to a barren woman's child.
This clarifies that although dharmas appear, they are all without real events.
A pure eye and a barren woman's child are not in the above text.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
The buddhas' teachings reach the time when they subtly correspond with the dusts.

It is said that when the buddhas appear in the world, they expound the Dharma, departing from the four propositions and transcending the hundred negations. Whether establishing or refuting, the ordinary mind and the holy measure cannot reach it.

When the great capacity has not yet encountered [the Dharma], they all use the four truths and the twelve links of dependent arising to realize cessation, cultivate the path, and liberate from birth and death as the beginning of the ford, not sharing the same characteristics as the non-Buddhists' supreme nature and spontaneity.
Although they initially expound the causes and conditions of the lesser vehicle, they are already superior to the profound and wonderful [teachings] of the non-Buddhists.
Great Wisdom!
The buddhas' teachings reach the time when they are like the leader of merchants skillfully guiding the masses.

In order to purify the two kinds of hindrances of afflictions and cognition, they are like the leader of merchants who guides the merchants, knowing the safe and dangerous paths, the faults, and the places to stop and stay.
And again, it is like the TathÄgata guiding sentient beings, eliminating the two hindrances, and causing them to abide in the place of peace within the dharma of no characteristics.
And again, it is the jewel that distinguishes the various vehicles and stages.

As for the two hindrances of delusion and cognition, the Awakening of Faith says: The sixth defiled mind is called the hindrance of afflictions, because it obstructs the fundamental wisdom of suchness.
The meaning of ignorance is called the hindrance of cognition, because it obstructs the wisdom of natural karmic activity in the world.
What is the meaning of this?
It is because, based on the defiled mind, one is able to see and manifest, mistakenly grasping at objects, and thus contradicting the nature of equality.
It is because all dharmas are always still, without any arising characteristics. Ignorance and non-awakening mistakenly contradict the dharmas, and thus one is unable to attain them.

It is because one accords with the world and knows the various objects in all ways. This clarifies the meaning of the two hindrances based on the mutual dependence of the fundamental and the derivative.
If we explain the two obstacles in terms of the two attachments, we will later cite the Cheng Weishi Lun to explain their meaning.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
There are four kinds of dhyana... dhyana that takes true suchness as its object... dhyana of the tathagatas.
Because the two obstacles above can obstruct the holy path, and one does not realize the two fruits of the transmutation of the basis, namely, the bodhi of the tathagatas and nirvana.

Those who study the Way should cultivate meditation and give rise to the wondrous wisdom of the uncontaminated [path], only then can they purify those two obstacles, therefore, the four kinds of dhyana are explained next.
It is also said that among the six perfections, the practice of meditation is the most spiritual and wondrous, and can give rise to the innate, superior, uncontaminated wisdom.
Myriad practices and virtues, up to and including spiritual powers and radiance, all arise from meditation.
